awd_abstract_narration:
Teams of humans are exceptionally good at coordination. Teams of robots, however, are extremely clumsy at coordination, requiring extensive communication and computation. Reliance on this infrastructure poses a significant roadblock to bringing robot teams into real-world applications. This project is pursuing an integrated research, education, and outreach approach for developing novel, data-driven algorithms for multi-robot coordination, inspired by human coordination. As cognitive beings that make decisions based on broad context, memory, and sensing, human capabilities are challenging to transfer to robotics. To facilitate this transfer, the project is developing an online crowdsourcing application that tasks participants with creating a global structure, such as a shape. The application constrains participants to robot-like capabilities by limiting available information and actions. The application will provide a faithful representation of the capabilities of distributed teams of robots, and will be used to gain insights into human coordination that can then be transferred to a multi-robot system.

The overarching goal of the proposed work is to develop novel methodologies for multi robot coordination firmly grounded in human collaboration, based on models learned from data collected via a crowdsourced online application. To this end, the research objectives are (1) to explicate the relationship between context (communication and sensing) and outcomes in distributed teams of humans working on tightly coupled tasks using data generated from an online multi-person interface; (2) to identify, using statistical methods, parameters for distributed teams of robots solving similar shared objective problems; (3) to infer, using deep learning architectures, diverse ensembles of coordination models for distributed teams of robots solving tightly coupled problems using the data collected from the crowdsourcing application; and (4) to validate these models by evaluating their success in solving tightly coupled problems using a combination of simulation, hardware, and mixed reality experiments.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the proposed work was to develop novel methodologies for multi robot coordination inspired by human collaboration, based on models learned from data collected via a crowdsourced online application. To this end, we developed a multiplayer game to collect data on human collaboration. The intent of the game is to put humans in a robot-like environment with robot-like capabilities, to observe how humans solve a problem we typically pose for teams of robots. The results were then analyzed to inspire new ideas for more effective collaboration of robots in real-world environments.

We achieved our goal of developing a finite state machine-based decentralized shape formation algorithm with human-inspired heuristics. Several papers were published alont the way, and the final publication, which details this algorithm is forthcoming. 

One idea we have reinforced with this project is of diversity in robot decision-making within a collective. Part of the reason human workgroups are able to solve difficult problems is diversity--each person can bring a different skill to the table, and these skills combined can solve more complex problems. In robotics, while physical heterogeneity has been studied, controller diversity has been studied very little. We have shown through our multi-player game that humans use diverse control policies, and we have based our robot algorithm on this policy, resulting in a distributed approach for coordinating robots. 

Our research objectives were to (1) to identify how diversity affects the outcomes of the game for humans, (2) how we can create diverse ensembles of coordination models for multirobot environments without explicitly coding those behaviors into the team, and (3) how machine learning tools can be used for robots to improve their decision making (i.e., control policies) online. These ideas were validated in a combination of simulation, mixed reality, and hardware experiments. This work is applicable in search and rescue, environmental monitoring, wildfire containment, any any scenario where robots must coordinate in an unknown, unstructured environment. 

Over the course of the project, we hosted multiple student groups and encouraged them to play our multiplayer game as an outreach activity. To expose undergraduate students to the research, the game was played in multiple undergraduate courses. Afterwards, a discussion was facilitated in which students shared how they played the game, and the difficulty of forming shapes without a full view of the playing field.  An “analog” version of the game was also played with elementary-aged students, using an overhead camera, a screen to show the resulting shape, and colored paper they held over their heads. The students were instructed toform shapes in a single color without communicating with each other. They learned how hard it is to coordinate without any form of communication (and how hard it is to stop communicating nonverbally). In this outreach activity, young students gained insight into how difficult coordination is without communication, and how difficult multi-robot problems are to solve. 

The project was successful in achieving its stated goas both for intellectual merit and also broader impacts. 


Last Modified: 08/21/2024
Modified by: Nora Ayanian
